ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
- A thorough overview of recent social theory, from the second half of the 20th century to as recent as 2017
- Practice in long, academic writing about theory
- Practice in weekly discussion about dense theoretical concepts
how to engage with sociological theory
We talked about a wide array of social thinkers, dealing with Black feminist thought, intersectionality, neoliberalism, etc. Many of the authors were people who I had never interacted with before.
We got to read a lot of amazing theory. We also gained some writing skills.
This class provided me with the insight and critical analysis skills necessary to evaluate contemporary theories and their impacts in Sociology today.

This course provide an overview of some of the most important topics and approaches in contemporary social theory, with subjects like class, power, and identity being articulated in a variety of ways be the different thinkers that we read. I gained skills in reading social theoretical works, synthesizing the ideas of different thinkers, and discussing complex and often personally relevant topics with my classmates.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Gorski and Anne (TF) did a great job of breaking down each theory and trying to apply it to situations or scenarios that we would be familiar with and could comprehend more easily. Sometimes, this included supplemented the longer/denser theory with a more recent article that was somehow related and using THAT as the jumping-off point for discussion.

Strengths: I think the class was set up to privilege student participation, and that was appreciated. Discussion was always fostered, and there was a very friendly relationship among the class that helped us to talk through ideas in productive ways. 
Weaknesses: I wouldn't have picked some of the readings tbh, (I think we could have read something for formative for when we introduced intersectionality, for instance).

The syllabus was wonderful, I loved the inclusion of Patricia Hill Collins, Crenshaw, and Pyle. I think the course should feature Black feminist theory more heavily though and perhaps more background information on non canonical scholars.

Strengths: very relevant and diverse theories and theorists. I really enjoyed the session where we had one of the theorists speak to us. The TA and the Professor were very warm, accessible, and engaging.

Weakness: 5pm deadlines don't compute in my head very well (I don't know if this is just a me issue or an issue for students in general). I think having discussion posts due 2 hours before class has been a very effective method in my other classes (as it still provides the professor/tas enough time to read the responses to prepare for class).
Strengths - I really enjoyed reading so many thinkers, and I believe this class did a lot to expand the sociological canon.

This course benefited from a great and diverse set of readings and an equally diverse group of students. The discussion format of the class made it easy to engage in the texts on a more intimate level, but occasionally discussions seemed too unstructured. More directed explanations of key topics and more clear guidelines to discussions would have helped to make the learning objectives of each class more clear.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The seminar format worked well over Zoom, and breakout rooms were used in the best possible way not overused, but used every so often for discussions in smaller groups that we would then discuss as a larger class.
Succeeded: Zoom format was good, the class worked well there.
I think the Zoom formatting is as engaging as one can possibly be given a pandemic setting.

Zoom software was used to help increase student participation in the virtual setting of the course, with the chat feature and breakout rooms coming into use. For the virtual breakout groups in particular, clearer guidelines for discussion could have made student participation flow more easily when instructors were not present in the room.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if they are interested in the specifics of social theory. Anyone who does not feel confident managing a heavy reading load should steer clear.
if planning on taking a sociology class

I think the syllabus could use a little bit of reworking, but otherwise, if you're interested in social theory it would be useful. The two paper assignments were also not the most interesting, but they also weren't bad per se.
Yes 100% especially with Phil Gorski and Anne Taylor.

I would recommend SOCY 152 to any student interested in social theory or society more generally and how thinkers have analyzed social systems and structures in critical and constructive ways. Students should enter the course ready to participate in open discussions about a variety of interesting readingssome of which they'll enjoy or agree with more than others. Students should expect less of a formal or comprehensive overview of social theory as a discipline, but more of a look at several notable trends or insights and how they've been developed by a diverse group of thinkers.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Zoom seminar 2x/week
This class was 100% a virtual semnar.
